articles.title: "I just want food for my children": The plea of a mother from Holguín who lost everything after Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa caused severe damage in the eastern part of Cuba. Activist Noly Blak travels through the affected areas documenting the situation of the affected families. A young mother from the municipality of Cacocum in the province of Holguín lost everything during the hurricane.

articles.title: Rare Atmospheric Shake-Up Could Lead To A Cold And Snowy December
articles.summary: A sudden stratospheric warming event is becoming more likely over the next few weeks. It could have major impacts on the weather for the month of December. It's possible that it could be very warm. It is also possible that the weather could get very cold.

articles.title: ‘Blow the joint up': Malcolm Turnbull unloads on Coalition climate change sceptics
articles.author: Samantha Maiden
articles.summary: Malcolm Turnbull criticises the Liberal Party's decision to dump net zero. He claims it sends a message that the Coalition is not serious about climate change. He blames the parties' 20-year battle over climate change for its woeful electoral standing. Sussan Ley insists she cares about the climate and the interests of 'Gen Z and millennials'.

articles.title: Letters for Nov. 14: Preparing for future climate is a smarter strategy
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: World leaders are in Brazil to update progress on climate change. Bill Gates and Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates believe we should focus on reducing poverty, adapting to the changes and leveraging innovation. Donald Trump has cut billions in science funding, canceled grants for some of America's most elite universities and revoked international student visas. The consensus among historians and political scientists is that Trump is among the worst presidents in American history.

articles.title: Growth of India's CO2 emissions expected to slow down significantly in 2025: Study
articles.author: Amitabh Sinha
articles.summary: India's carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel sources are expected to increase by 1.4% in 2025. This is lower than the 4% growth registered the previous year. An early monsoon reduced cooling requirements in the hottest months in India and strong growth in renewables led to a low growth in coal consumption. Global Carbon Budget study is published in the Nature journal and coincides with the annual climate conference COP30 being held in Brazil.

articles.title: Labor must not partner with climate vandals on Australia's new environmental laws
articles.author: Tim Flannery
articles.summary: Tony Abbott's government abolished the Climate Commission in 2013. The Albanese government is rewriting Australia's most important environment law, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. It's critical that PM doesn't try to cut deals on this law with the same climate deniers who dismantled Australia's climate ambition last time.

articles.title: Active end to November could lead to potential Polar Vortex infused cold and snow to start December
articles.author: Kieran Sullivan
articles.summary: La Niña will play a starring role in the United States' winter weather. La Niña is a part of a natural climate cycle known as El Niño-Southern Oscillation. The cycle swings between warmer and cooler seawater in a region along the equator in the tropical Pacific Ocean.

articles.title: Late Autumn Leaves: Why Are They Still Hanging On?
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: Leaves are lingering on trees long after their usual autumnal descent because of a changing climate. Delayed leaf senescence is becoming more common due to warmer autumns and urban heat island effect. The economic implications of the changing season are significant for industries that rely on the traditional fall foliage season.

articles.title: ‘They don't feel it's worth protecting our citizens': Ketan Joshi cuts through this week's climate bullshit
articles.author: Crystal Andrews
articles.summary: The Coalition has decided to ditch net zero. Crikey climate contributor Ketan Joshi says it's not a big deal. Joshi explains which policies and amendments could change the game for Australia and talks about the bid to host COP31. Cut Through is a weekly podcast with Crystal Andrews, journalists and readers' editor.

articles.title: Global Philanthropies Unite to Combat Rising Climate Health Risks with $300 Million Pledge
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A coalition of philanthropies announced a $300 million initiative to address health risks posed by rising global temperatures. The fund aims to foster data development and strategic investments to mitigate extreme heat, air pollution, and infectious diseases. Vulnerable groups, including children and pregnant women, are most at risk in this precarious climate future.

articles.title: Cabo San Lucas water fight grows after 40 dry days
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Residents of Casa Blanca neighborhood in Cabo San Lucas say water has not been arriving for more than a month. In a written petition, families document over 40 days without potable water while residential bills keep climbing. The water supply has not stopped, but the charges have not.

articles.title: Parties debate how to incorporate 1.5°C goal in COP30 text
articles.author: Jayashree Nandi
articles.summary: This year is set to be either the second or third warmest year on record, according to the State of the Global Climate Update of WMO. It is now virtually impossible to prevent an overshoot of the Paris Agreement's lower limit of 1.5 degree C. Parties are debating how the latest science on climate change can be framed in the COP30 decision. The Arab group and India rejected linkages to the GST.

articles.title: State Department issues warning in Japan after bears kill 13 since April
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Japan has seen 13 bear attack fatalities between April and November 2025, the highest yearly toll since records began in the early 2000s. Countermeasures include deploying hunters, riot police, and troops to cull bears, but their effectiveness remains uncertain. Climate change has affected bear food sources and depopulation of rural areas.

articles.title: Researchers Warn of Groundwater Threats to Aging Urban Infrastructure
articles.author: Frank Carini
articles.summary: Groundwater rise as a result of climate change poses a significant threat to coastal cities, according to University of Rhode Island assistant professor of geosciences Christopher Russoniello. He is part of a team of researchers studying flooding in the town of Warren.

articles.title: The Weeknd Donates $350K to Jamaican Families Affected by Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Ilana Kaplan
articles.summary: The Weeknd will donate $350,000 from his XO Humanitarian Fund to the World Food Programme's emergency response in the aftermath of Hurricane Melissa. Since Hurricane Melissa hit at the end of October, nearly six million people across the Caribbean islands have been affected. The Weeknd has donated more than $10 million to humanitarian causes since 2020. In July, he received the Key to the City from the City of Toronto.

articles.title: From climate crisis to AI catastrophe: The future no one is ready for
articles.author: Independent Australia
articles.summary: Mark Beeson is worried about the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) and the global warming. He is also concerned about the lack of international cooperation on climate change and the development of AI. Beeson believes some people are making money from business as usual and some politicians are deluded about the future.

articles.title: Influencer started ‘illegal fire' on Australia island, rangers say. She's fined
articles.author: Aspen Pflughoeft
articles.summary: A social media influencer filmed herself starting an illegal campfire on K'gari Island off the eastern coast of Australia and posted it on Facebook. She's been fined and warned by environmental officials. The island is a World Heritage environment site formerly known as Fraser Island.

articles.title: As Maine winters get warmer, Presque Isle faces the biggest change
articles.author: Penelope Overton
articles.summary: Presque Isle's winter is 6.5 degrees warmer now than it was in 1970. It's the eighth-fastest warming winter among 244 U.S. cities tracked. Maine's winters are two weeks shorter than they were in the early 1900s. Maine may be 2 to 4 degrees warmer by 2050 and up to 10 degrees hotter by 2100.

articles.title: Invisible groundwater threatens aging urban infrastructure, researchers warn
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Groundwater rise as a result of climate change poses a significant threat to coastal cities, says the University of of Florida.      Â   "Climate change is changing the environment and affecting groundwater levels in coastal cities".  "There is a significant risk of groundwater rise in coastal areas due to climate change."

articles.title: COP30 climate pledges favor unrealistic land-based carbon removal over emission cuts, says report
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: An analysis of national climate plans released today at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil warns that countries are not taking climate change seriously enough and are not doing enough to prepare for it.      Â   y   i   a

articles.title: Cantor: Report warns of major flood risk for Long Island economy
articles.author: Long Island Business News
articles.summary: New data shows 34,000 Long Island businesses face major flood risks that could cost billions in economic losses. It's been 13 years since Superstorm Sandy hit Long Island.       .   i   on Long Island Businesses are at risk.

articles.title: Cities at Risk: Climate Change's Melting Impact
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Cities are experiencing unprecedented transformations due to climate change. Urban planners and policymakers must recognize that cities are both culprits and victims of climate change and potential laboratories for innovative responses to these challenges. Technology serves as both a monitoring tool for climate impacts and a means to implement proactive strategies. Urban resilience should hinge on inclusive strategies that engage all community members in dialogue.

articles.title: Tech roundup: Why this county is losing residents, Electric air taxis could take off from private airports
articles.author: Ashley Portero
articles.summary: Miami-Dade County lost 67,000 residents in 2024. The loss could be tied to the region's penchant for flooding.    in 2024, because of the weather-related problems in the area.  in the future, more people will die.

articles.title: Battle brews over Australia or Turkey hosting next COP
articles.author: Black Hills Pioneer
articles.summary: Diplomats at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil are looking for a good coffee. There are two options for them: Australians pouring flat whites or Turkish offering strong brews next door. They choose the Turkish one.   Â. Â

articles.title: Beach flags, warnings confuse international visitors
articles.author: Alex Mitchell
articles.summary: Australia's beaches continue to pose fatal risks to overseas-born people. Study suggests many people don't understand warnings on beach warning signs.    for help with reading beach warnings on signs, visit www.beachwise.com.au.  for more information.

articles.title: Formidable Challenges
articles.author: Malik Muhammad Ashraf
articles.summary: Half of Pakistan's population lives below the poverty line. The 2022 monsoon floods submerged a third of the country, affecting 33 million people and causing $30 billion in damage. The 2025 floods displaced millions more and killed nearly a thousand. Pakistan is one of the seven most affected countries from climate change, which is the biggest blow to the growth of the economy. The impact of corruption at the higher echelons of the government has trickle-down effect on the lowest rungs of society.

articles.title: Icy Silence From Climate Doomers As Controversial Study Warns Of Possible Ice Age
articles.author: Simon Kent
articles.summary: A new ice age could be ushered in as a result of shifts in a key Atlantic current, according to a new study. The current is the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), a 'conveyor belt of the ocean' that funnels warm water toward the ocean surface. Iceland has designated AMOC's potential collapse an existential threat and has begun planning for worst-case scenarios.

articles.title: We need to talk about our fossil fuel addiction: UNEP chief
articles.author: Nick Perry Afp
articles.summary: UNEP chief Inger Andersen says the world is making progress to bend the curb on global warming, but not fast enough, as she says in the video. In the video, Inger explains the UNEP's position on the global warming issue in more detail.

articles.title: When the Land Fights Back: How climate change drives migration and conflict in Ghana's Savannah Region
articles.summary: Rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and the march of the Sahara are destroying farmlands and water sources in Ghana's Savannah Region. The result is growing tension between local farmers and migrant herdsmen, each struggling to survive on shrinking land. In 2023, a clash between a migrant herder and a charcoal burner over access to water in a suburb of Daboya, North Gonja District, led to the death of the charcoal burner. Alhaji Yakubu Musah Barry, General Secretary of the Fulbes community in Ghana, said his people are not intentionally destroying farms.

articles.title: Climate Goals Threatened by Industrialised Animal Farming, Reveals Key International Study
articles.author: pressadvantage
articles.summary: A new study in Animals argues that industrialized animal farming is one of the most powerful forces driving the climate and biodiversity crises. The study synthesizes evidence from 47 international studies and concludes that reducing livestock production and embracing plant-based food systems is essential for meeting global climate goals. Animal agriculture occupies over 80% of agricultural land, while providing only 18% of calories and 37% of protein.

articles.title: Cantor: Report warns of major flood risk for Long Island economy
articles.author: Opinion
articles.summary: It's been 13 years since Superstorm Sandy hit Long Island and caused billions of dollars of damages. LiRo-Hill GIS services report shows the economic consequences if another 'superstorm' makes landfall on Long Island. 34,178 of Long Island's nearly 100,000 businesses could risk significant economic loss from flooding should another significant storm hit the region.

articles.title: 'Ego manoeuvring' behind the scenes at COP30, Pacific delegate at the UN climate talks says
articles.author: Rnz Pacific Journalist
articles.summary: COP30 began in Belém on Monday. Pacific Islands Forum's climate adviser Karlos Lee Moresi is at the talks. Australia and Türkiye are in negotiations to host COP31 next year. Pacific's position throughout each COP is "1.5C to stay alive" and improving access to climate finance. Rescue workers in Papua New Guinea are scrambling to relocate about 300 people living on unstable earth.

articles.title: Climate Alarmists Find a New Way We're All Gonna Die
articles.author: Tom Knighton
articles.summary: A key Atlantic current could be pushed to the brink of collapse within decades, which would usher in a new ice age and dramatically raise sea levels, according to a new study published in the journal Communications Earth & Environment. Bill Gates downplayed the impact of temperature fluctuations on the planet weeks ago.

articles.title: Researcher warns about data gap on wars' effects on climate change
articles.author: DPA
articles.summary: The military is responsible for 5.5% of annual greenhouse gas emissions around the planet. If the world's military were a single country, it would have the fourth-largest carbon footprint of all states. The European Union and NATO states are planning to increase their military spending.

articles.title: Can the world adapt to climate change?
articles.author: Joel Mathis
articles.summary: World leaders are gathering this week for the COP30 climate summit in Brazil to discuss climate change adaptation efforts. Developing countries will need $310 billion a year to buy air conditioners and fans, AI mapping of soil conditions to improve crop yields and other adaptation tools. The United States is not sending any top officials to the summit.

articles.title: The Weeknd Donates $350K to Hurricane Melissa Relief Efforts in Jamaica
articles.author: Maravi Post
articles.summary: The Weeknd is donating $350,000 from his XO Humanitarian Fund to support the World Food to help Jamaicans affected by Hurricane Melissa. The 'Blinding Lights' singer is donating a lot of money to help put food on their tables.

articles.title: 'Little to No Measurable Progress' on Climate as World on Track for 2.6°C: Report
articles.author: Olivia Rosane
articles.summary: The world is on track for a disastrous 2.6°C of fossil fuel-driven warming, according to an annual analysis released on Thursday. It is the fourth year in a row in which there had been "little to no progress" in warming predictions for 2100 based on the current policies and commitments of 40 countries. The United States is actively shutting down offshore wind projects, rolling back renewable energy incentives, cutting curbs on carbon pollution, and actively expanding oil and gas production.

articles.title: Sun Unleashes Strongest Flare of 2025, Causing Global Radio Blackouts
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: On November 11, 2025, the Sun erupted with an X5.1-class flare, disrupting shortwave communications across Africa and Europe. The flare's X-rays and UV radiation ionized Earth's upper atmosphere, disrupting Earth's shortwave communication.

articles.title: La Niña To Last Through Winter; What That Means
articles.author: The Weather Channel
articles.summary: La Niña conditions continued over the past month and will last through winter, according to NOAA's Climate Prediction Center. The weather is expected to get worse in the next few days.    .   i   in the coming weeks.  in

articles.title: Shouting at seagulls may stop them from stealing food
articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Exeter carried out an experiment where they put a box of chips on the ground to attract herring gulls. They played three different sound effects to deter the gulls from stealing the chips. The shouting was the most effective, but the robin sound effect was the least effective.

articles.title: NOAA: La Niña expected for beginning of winter, neutral conditions likely in 2026
articles.author: Julian Atienza
articles.summary: La Niña will play a starring role in the United States' winter weather. La Niña is a part of a natural climate cycle known as El Niño-Southern Oscillation. The cycle swings between warmer and cooler seawater in a region along the equator in the tropical Pacific Ocean.

articles.title: World still headed toward 2.6°C of warming despite record fossil fuel use: report
articles.author: Madhyamam
articles.summary: The planet is on course for a 2.6°C temperature rise above pre-industrial levels by 2100, according to new reports. The findings were released ahead of the COP30 meeting.    The report was released by the UNFCCC.

articles.title: Early climate models got global warming right – but now US funding cuts threaten the future of climate science data
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Early climate models got global warming right, but now US funding cuts threaten the future of climate science data, as The Conversation points out.       .   The Conversation is a website that provides news and information about the science of climate change.

articles.title: ASEAN can't let Trump's America set the pace on climate action
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Trump's climate retreat is ASEAN's moment to lead
articles.author: Nik Nazmi Nik Ahmad
articles.summary: The developed world needs to listen to developing and less developed countries on how climate change should be addressed. Developed countries should bring their chequebooks and increase their climate finance commitments. The Tropical Forest Forever Facility (TFFF), proposed by Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, is an important part of the solution.

articles.title: Measuring poverty in the age of climate
articles.author: Knut Ostby
articles.summary: This year's Global MPI Report 2025 covers 109 countries representing 6.3 billion people. It finds that 1.1 billion people live in multidimensional poverty, most of them in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. For the first time, the report links poverty data with climate risk. Nearly 80% of the world's poor live in areas exposed to at least one of four major climate hazards: extreme heat, drought, flooding, or air pollution. In the Philippines, 3.9% of population are multidimensionally poor, while another 5.2% are at risk.

articles.title: Beyond 1.5: Why the global climate target still matters
articles.author: Climate Change Correspondent
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement was signed ten years ago to limit global warming to well below 2°C and pursue efforts to limit the increase to 1.5°C. UN Environment Programme report says the dream is over, and the best the world can achieve is to spend as little time above 1°C as possible. New Zealand climate scientist Dr Andy Reisinger is a climate change commissioner.

articles.title: Global CO2 emissions are set to reach a new high
articles.summary: Emissions from fossil fuel use will reach a record high this year despite countries' pledges to reduce their climate pollution. The rise in CO2 comes as the amount taken up by oceans and land shrinks. The United States is responsible for more CO2 than any other country and ranks second annually.

articles.title: Belém Health Action Plan: A new global health blueprint finds urgent relevance in Africa
articles.summary: Belem Health Action Plan was launched at COP30. Its three core pillars are adaptation, equity and climate justice. The new Climate and Health Funders Coalition has committed an initial $300 million to convert the Belem health action plan into real-world results.

articles.title: We're Driving Massive Wedge Between Ourselves and Nature
articles.author: Frank Carini
articles.summary: A recent study found that human connection to the natural world has declined by some 60% since 1800. Frank Carini believes we need to change our relationship with Nature and give Nature self-protective rights. He believes we can't live without a healthy, productive natural world.

articles.title: Icy Silence from Climate Doomers as Controversial Study Outlines Possible New Ice Age
articles.author: Breitbart
articles.summary: A new ice age and sea level changes could be ushered in as a result of climate change. There are no imminent threats of "global boiling" at the moment, but there could be new ice ages or sea levels changes.   Â

articles.title: Misinformation risk if climate change sceptic tours NZ, councillor says
articles.author: Ella Scott-Fleming
articles.summary: Groundswell NZ is fundraising to bring a former member of the Trump administration and a climate change sceptic to New Zealand. Dr William Happer has long been critical of the idea climate change is caused by humans. Southland regional councillor Phil Morrison says both the advocacy group and Dr Happer are guilty of gaslighting and misinformation.

articles.title: Battle brews over Australia or Turkey hosting next COP
articles.author: Nick Perry AFP
articles.summary: Diplomats are drinking coffee at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil. Australia and Turkey are locked in a stalemate over who should host next year's UN climate talks, so they don't have the same access to good coffee as the Australians and the Turks.

articles.title: Que pensent les climatologues de Suisse de l'état du climat?
articles.author: Swi Swissinfo.Ch
articles.summary: Swissinfo.ch's journalist and data scientist covers climate and sustainability topics with a data-driven perspective. She is passionate about exploring practical ways to reduce our environmental footprint and inspire others to do the same. She combines storytelling and analysis to uncover the facts behind Switzerland's green transition.

articles.title: Rain, floods & storms: why Irish weather conditions are getting wetter
articles.author: RTÉ Brainstorm
articles.summary: There are more severe weather events in Ireland and worldwide due to climate change. 2023 was the wettest year on record in Ireland. Rainfall in the early months of 2024 was also above average. Brainstorm podcast talks to Prof Conor Murphy from the ICARUS Climate Research Centre and Dr Ruth Quinn from the Department of Civil Engineering & Construction at IT Sligo.

articles.title: Zanzibar women turn to sponge farming as oceans heat up
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: Women in Zanzibar's turquoise shallow tides wade through the ocean every morning to tend their sponge farms. Rising ocean temperatures, overfishing and pollution have steadily degraded marine ecosystems around the world, but sponges exist in the ocean.

articles.title: If the Amazon Rainforest is the lungs, then COP30 is the ass
articles.author: Tom
articles.summary: There are scientific fallacies abound at COP30, the UN climate change conference being held this month in Belem, Brazil. The world doesn't have a thermostat that we could control temperature. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a minor contributor to the Earth's climate.

articles.title: Swiss town records 23.5° November heat record
articles.author: Swi Swissinfo.Ch
articles.summary: New heat record in November: 23.5° recorded in Delémont Keystone-SDA. The last record was set in 2023, when the temperature was 22.8°. In Vaduz, in the Principality of Liechtenstein, the current record is 23.7°. The weather services are forecasting mild temperatures for tomorrow, Friday.

articles.title: Global CO₂ Emissions Hit Record High In 2025: Pakistan Faces Mounting Energy Challenges
articles.author: Asim Ahmed Khan
articles.summary: Global carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels are set to reach an all-time high in 2025. Fossil fuel emissions are projected to rise by 1.1 percent. Renewable energy adoption is accelerating, but it is insufficient to offset growing global energy demand. Since 1960, climate-related changes have reduced the ability of land and ocean sinks to absorb carbon by 8%. The natural carbon sinks are weakening due to climate change.

articles.title: Watch live: Pelosi, House Democrats give remarks on COP30, climate change
articles.author: The Hill Staff
articles.summary: The United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP30) began last week in Brazil. Nancy Pelosi and Democratic members of the House Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition will speak with reporters Thursday morning about rising threats of climate change. The event is scheduled to begin at 9:30 a.m. EST.

articles.title: Health at COP30: Is climate change a health crisis?
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Rising temperatures have driven 12 of 20 key indicators tracking health threats related to climate change to record levels over the past year. Extreme weather events such as heatwaves, floods, and storms are occurring more frequently and becoming more severe. Heat-related illnesses, including heatstroke, are increasing, especially among vulnerable groups like the elderly and outdoor workers. Rising temperatures are expanding the habitats of disease-carrying mosquitoes, which raises the risk of vector-borne diseases such as malaria and dengue fever. The Belém Health Action Plan will be introduced at COP30's Health Day. It seeks to galvanize global efforts to develop climate-resilient and environmentally sustainable health systems.

articles.title: World's carbon budget 'virtually exhausted' as fossil emissions surge
articles.summary: Emissions from fossil fuels are set to reach a record high in 2025, according to the Global Carbon Budget Report. The report calculates the remaining amount of carbon that can be emitted to keep global warming below the 1.5°C goal set by the Paris Agreement. The Paris Agreement does appear to have had some impact on global emissions. However, it is still too fragile to translate into a sustained decrease in emissions.

articles.title: Thoothukudi witnesses light to moderate rainfall; fishermen advised to stay ashore
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Thoothukudi district experienced light to moderate rainfall after a couple of weeks of dry weather. The fresh phase of northeast monsoon is beginning across various parts of the State. There is a heavy wind warning and fishermen are advised not to venture into the sea until further notice.

articles.title: Cop30 live: calls for ‘just transition' plan grow as report warns world on track for ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Climate Action Tracker report finds pledges made in past year have not cut the forecast for global heating. Young people from around the world have come to Cop30 in full force, writes Dharna Noor, fossil fuels and climate reporter for Climate Action Tracker (CAT).

articles.title: Global CO2 Emissions Reach Record High 38 Billion Tons
articles.author: Bethell Seese
articles.summary: 2025 will see record high of fossil fuel CO 2 emissions at 38.1 billion tons. The United States' emissions are projected to increase by 1.9% and the EU by 0.4%. In the past decade, emissions from deforestation remained high at around 4 billion tons of carbon dioxide per year.

articles.title: Jamaica reports US$192 million crop losses after Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has caused significant damage to Jamaica's agriculture sector. Agriculture Minister Floyd Green estimates the losses at J$29.5 billion (approximately US$191.8 million). Domestic crop losses include 32,400 hectares of vegetables, valued at $8 billion (US$52 million) and affecting 47,500 farmers. Sweet pepper, tomato, lettuce, cabbage, carrot, and vine crops such as melon and cantaloupe experienced the most damage. Banana and plantain production also recorded major losses.

articles.title: Ocean Warming and Its Cascading Effects: Beyond Rising Seas – [your]NEWS
articles.author: Victor Olaitan
articles.summary: Oceans are heating up faster than ever. More than 90% of the heat trapped by greenhouse gases end up in the ocean. The North Atlantic and Pacific are several degrees warmer than historical averages. The Atlantic hurricane season in 2025 has seen multiple systems intensify in hours. The Great Barrier Reef has seen another mass bleaching event this year. Most of the world's reefs could face annual bleaching by the mid-2030s if warming continues. Global fish production may fall by 20% in the next few decades.

articles.title: The 1.5°C target—an obituary?
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: "The truth is that we have failed to avoid an overshooting above 1.5°C in the next few years," says the minister.       .   "The truth  is that  we have tried to avoid it, but we haven't succeeded."

articles.title: Paperwork won't prepare us for climate change: Planning might
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: climate talks at COP30 shift from setting lofty targets to setting practical ones.    for the future of the climate change.  For more information, go to: http://www.council30.org/climate-change-talks-on-policies-and-practicalities.

articles.title: In pictures: Colourful displays of Aurora Borealis, Aurora Australis delight skywatchers across the world
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Displays of Northern Lights have been reported across unusually large swaths of the US this week. Skywatchers across large parts of Australia and New Zealand were treated to a celestial delight yesterday evening. A severe solar storm made it possible to view the Southern Lights, or Aurora Australis.

articles.title: The insiders changing how we think about flying
articles.summary: Aviation accounts for 2.5% of global CO2 emissions and 4% of human-driven warming. The United Nations warns that without intervention, those emissions could triple by 2050. Just 1% of the world's population is responsible for more than half of all passenger aviation emissions, while most people never board a plane at all. Private flights have surged since the Covid-19 pandemic, rising nearly 50% since 2019. Eight countries, including France, Spain, Kenya and Barbados launched a coalition that aims to introduce a levy on private jets.

articles.title: Northern Lights dazzle again: Second stunning aurora display lights up the sky
articles.summary: The Northern Lights, also known as Auroras, are ribbons of light weaving across Earth's northern or southern polar regions. They are caused by magnetic storms that have been triggered by solar activity. Energetic charged particles from these events are carried away from the sun by the solar wind.

articles.title: Kerry's Skellig Michael at risk of damage due to climate change, report warns
articles.author: Anne Lucey
articles.summary: Report on the potential impact of climate change on Skellig island off the coast of Kerry warns of deterioration of built structures and impacts on birdlife and on tourism. The Great Skelligs island is one of 10 international sites examined under the National Geographic Society's Preserving Legacies Project. Other sites vulnerable under scrutiny include Petra in Jordan and Angkor in Cambodia.

articles.title: Paperwork Won't Prepare Us for Climate Change: Planning Might
articles.author: Phys.org
articles.summary: At COP30, Australia has strengthened its climate resilience rules. The draft Treasury Transition Planning Guide shows that Australia is making progress, but needs to focus on transforming systems that will enable us to achieve the ambitious targets set by the global climate negotiations at COP30.

articles.title: 1.5 degrees ‘no longer plausible' as global emissions hit record
articles.author: Benjamin Storrow
articles.summary: The world is on track to set a new record for greenhouse gas emissions this year. The Paris Agreement's most ambitious climate target envisioned limiting global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The world has virtually extinguished the carbon budget needed to meet that target. The biggest questions going forward are in China, which accounts for 32 percent of global emissions.

articles.title: Six ways Minnesotans are feeling the state's changing climate
articles.author: Jake Steinberg
articles.summary: Minnesota has warmed 3.2 degrees Fahrenheit since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution. It is among the fastest-warming states in the country. Snow is becoming wetter and heavier and melts more frequently in winter. In the summer, Minnesotans are exposed to unhealthy air thanks to wildfire smoke and major rainstorms. The number of state-issued air quality alerts has risen dramatically since 2008.

articles.title: ‘No clear peak' for global fossil fuel emissions
articles.author: Jeronimo Gonzalez
articles.summary: Global fossil fuel emissions are on track to surpass records this year. The increase in oil and gas production, led by the US, has boosted global emissions. Global leaders are meeting in Brazil for COP30, the world's most important environmental gathering.
